awd_titl_txt: Fifth International IEEE Conference on Computational Advances in Bio and medical Sciences (ICCABS) - Travel Awards
awd_abstract_narration: Advances in high-throughput technologies such as DNA sequencing and mass spectrometry are profoundly transforming life sciences, resulting in the collection of unprecedented amounts of biological and medical data. Using this data to advance our knowledge about fundamental biological processes and improve human health requires novel computational models and advanced analysis algorithms. IEEE ICCABS (International Conference on Computational Advances in Bio and Medical Sciences) aims to bring together leading academic and industry researchers to discuss the latest advances in computational methods for bio and medical sciences.  The award would provide funding for students and junior researchers to participate in this international meeting that covers a range of topics from structure bioinformatics to systems biology and high performance Biocomputing.  The conference proceeding ae made available both online and in special journal publications.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
1. Conference Summary

The Sixth ICCABS was held at the Klaus Advanced Computing Building, Georgia Institute of Technology Atlanta, October 13th to October 15th, 2016.

 

The conference was a great success as reported by the attendees. Around 70 persons attended the conference. All the talks were well attended and appreciated. The social events were also a big success!

 

Funds from NSF were used to support 12 graduate students and two post-doctoral fellows who represented 9 different US universities, NIH, and one university each from Brazil and Switzerland.

 

2. Objectives

Computational techniques are revolutionizing the way in which research is conducted in science and engineering. Unsurpassed advances have been made in various areas. This is particularly true in the domains of biology, medicine, and drug discovery.  The proposed conference has the goal of brining together scientists in all the three areas and hence serving as a platform for bridging the research efforts in these areas.

 

3. Conference Topics

The topics of interest to the conference spanned biology, medicine, and drug discovery. Some of the broader topics covered were: Biomedical image processing, Biomedical data and literature mining, Biological Big Data, Computational genetic epidemiology, Computational metabolomics, Computational proteomics, Databases and ontologies, Gene regulation, Genome analysis, Health Informatics, High-performance bio-computing, Immunoinformatics, Molecular evolution, Population genomics, Sequence analysis, Structural bioinformatics, Systems biology, Transcriptomics, etc.

 

4. Organizational Structure

The steering committee consisted of distinguished scientists: Srinivas Aluru (Iowa State University), Reda A. Ammar (University of Connecticut), Tao Jiang (UC Riverside), Vipin Kumar (University of Minnesota), Ming Li (University of Waterloo), Sanguthevar Rajasekaran (Chair, University of Connecticut), John Reif (Duke University), and Sartaj Sahni (University of Florida).

 

General Chairs of the conference were Srinivas Aluru (Georgia Institute of Technology) and Sanguthevar Rajasekaran (University of Connecticut). Program Chairs were Scott Emrich (University of Notre Dame) and Li-San Wang (University of Pennsylvania). Yury Khudyakov (CDC), Ion Mandoiu (University of Connecticut), Pavel Skums (Genorgia State University), and Alex Zelikovsky (Georgia State University) served as Workshop Chairs. Publicity Chair was Bob Weiner (University of Connecticut). Reda A. Ammar (University of Connecticut) and Mukul Bansal (University of Connecticut) were Finance Chairs. Local Arrangements were handled by Sharma Valliyil Thankachan (Georgia Institute of Technology).

 

The Program Committee had around 25 members.

 

5. Meeting Format

The Conference was held over a 2.5-day span, following usual Conference conventions. There were two parallel sessions. The technical program included 18 extended abstracts selected by the Program Committee from 45 full submissions received in response to the call for papers. In addition, there were 5 poster presentations. The program also included two workshops (the 6th Workshop on Computational Advances for Next Generation Sequencing (CANGS) and the 5th Workshop on Computational Advances in Molecular Epidemiology (CAME)). CANGS was organized by Ion Mandoiu, Pavel Skums, and Alex Zelikovsky. CAME was organized by Yury Khudyakov, Ion Mandoiu, and Alex Zelikovsky. The two workshops had a total of 21 presentations. There were keynote talks by three distinguished speakers, namely, Russell Schwartz from Carnegie Mellon University, May Wang from the Georgia Institute of Technology, and Cathy H. Wu from the University of Delaware. There were also seven invited talks from established researchers: Mukul Bansal from the University of Connecticut, Krishna Karuturi from the Jackson Laboratory, Yury Khudyakov from CDC, Yuk Yee Leung from the University of Pennsylvania, Rahul Singh from the San Francisco State University, Jejune Tang from the University of South Carolina, and Ellen Tsai from Partners.

 

6. Outcomes and Dissemination

Authors of accepted papers submitted full papers. These papers were put together to produce the Proceedings for IEEE. These proceedings are available online in the IEEE Xplore digital library. Each participant was supplied with a copy of the Proceedings in a flash memory stick.

 

Out of the full papers accepted for presentation in the conference and the workshop presentations, expanded versions of 25 papers have been invited for two journal special issues. In particular, 10 papers have been invited for a special issue of BMC Bioinformatics and another 15 papers have been invited for a special issue of BMC Genomics. These two special issues will be edited by the General Chairs, Program Chairs, and the Workshop Chairs. These papers will go through an additional set of reviews. We expect that these special issues will be finalized soon.

 

 


Last Modified: 06/07/2017
Modified by: Sanguthevar Rajasekaran
